newsitem.title: HUNGARY: France's Le Pen draws big crowd in Hungary.
newsitem.headline: France's Le Pen draws big crowd in Hungary.

text.p: French far-right politician Jean-Marie Le Pen and the Hungarian Justice and Life Party drew at least 20,000 people to a rally outside parliament on Sunday, making it the country's biggest political gathering in years.
The enthusiastic crowd heard Le Pen denounce the European Union's Maastricht treaty and the notion of a European super-state.
"The Europe of Maastricht, a federal Europe is just a step towards globalisation and it deliberately drives towards the destruction of nation states," he told them
"Globalisation...aims at destroying nations, our humanist and Christian civilisation."
The audience, which some estimates put as large as 30,000, was much larger than those at ceremonies last week commemorating Hungary's doomed 1956 uprising against Soviet rule.

"Who else can bring so many people to the streets in Hungary as we do?" Justice and Life leader Istvan Csurka asked reporters as the crowd chanted demands for the resignation of Hungary's Socialist-Liberal coalition government.

Csurka's party failed to get into parliament in the 1994 elections but draws crowds from a population hit by the inflation and unemployment which have accompanied Hungary's transition to a market economy.
